Last year, some friends and I got really into crossword puzzles and set out to construct a puzzle for the New York Times. I don’t want to get into the details right now, but the puzzle idea required finding a crossword grid that satisfied a pretty strict set of constraints. The search for this magical grid turned into an unnecessarily-complicated-but-really-fun coding project with some cool extensions. It’s been around a year but I’ve been really bored during quarantine, so figured I might as well write it up!

For the rest of this post, I will use X and - to represent black and white squares, respectively.

What defines a valid crossword grid?

A valid New York Times crossword puzzle typically satisfies the following constraints:

  1. The white squares are fully connected.
  2. It is rotationally symmetric. A useful way to think about this is that the first row should be the reverse of the last row, the second row should be the reverse of the second-to-last row, etc.
  3. Every answer must be at least three letters long.

For example, the following 5x5 grid is invalid beacuse the white squares aren’t fully connected:

X X - - -
- X - - -
- - X - -
- - - X X
- - - - X

The following grid is connected, but it isn’t rotationally symmetric:

X X - - -
- - - - -
- - - - -
- - - - X
- - - - X

And the following is connected and rotationally symmetric, but it has clue answers with lengths 1 and 2 (for example, see the first row and last column):

X X - - X
X - - - -
X - - - X
- - - - X
X - - X X

The following grid satisfies all the conditions:

X X - - -
X - - - -
- - - - -
- - - - X
- - - X X
